Malaria.Description: A mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Plasmodium parasites.
Malaria.Causes: Plasmodium parasites transmitted through the bites of infected female Anopheles Mosquitoes
Malaria.Prevention: Insecticide-treated bed nets, indoor residual spraying, antimalarial drugs

Typhoid Fever.Description: A bacterial infection spread through contaminated food or water.
Typhoid Fever.Symptoms: Prolonged fever, fatigue, headache, nausea, abdominal pain, constipation or diarrhea
Typhoid Fever.Causes: Infection by Salmonella Typhi bacteria through contaminated food or water
Typhoid Fever.Prevention: Vaccination, safe drinking water, proper sanitation, good hygiene practices

Common Cold(Rhinovirus).Description: A viral infection affecting the upper respiratory tract, commonly known as a cold.
Common Cold(Rhinovirus).Symptoms: Runny nose, sore throat, coughing, sneezing, headaches, body aches
Common Cold(Rhinovirus).Causes: Rhinoviruses(most common cause), other respiratory viruses
Common Cold(Rhinovirus).Prevention: Wash hands often, avoid close contact with sick individuals
Common Cold(Rhinovirus).Treatment: Rest, hydration, over-the-counter medications(pain relievers, decongestants, cough syrups)

Influenza(Flu).Description: A viral respiratory illness, also known as the flu.
Influenza(Flu).Symptoms: Fever, cough, sore throat, muscle pain, headache, fatigue, sometimes vomiting and diarrhea
Influenza(Flu).Causes: Influenza viruses(primarily type A and B)
Influenza(Flu).Prevention: Annual vaccination, hand hygiene, avoiding close contact with infected individuals
Influenza(Flu).Treatment: Rest, hydration, antiviral drugs(e.g., oseltamivir), over-the-counter symptom relief medications

Acute Bronchitis.Description: Inflammation of the bronchial tubes, often due to infection.
Acute Bronchitis.Symptoms: Cough(often with mucus), wheezing, shortness of breath, chest discomfort
Acute Bronchitis.Causes: Usually caused by viral infections(e.g., cold viruses), sometimes by bacteria
Acute Bronchitis.Prevention: Good hygiene practices, avoiding tobacco smoke, staying away from sick individuals
Acute Bronchitis.Treatment: Rest, hydration, over-the-counter medication for cough and pain

Chronic Bronchitis.Description: Long-term inflammation of the bronchi, often linked to smoking.
Chronic Bronchitis.Symptoms: Persistent cough with mucus, wheezing, shortness of breath
Chronic Bronchitis.Causes: Long-term exposure to irritants(e.g., tobacco smoke, air pollution)
Chronic Bronchitis.Prevention: Avoiding tobacco smoke, reducing exposure to pollutants, vaccination against respiratory infections
Chronic Bronchitis.Treatment: Bronchodilators, steriods, pulmonary rehabilitation, oxygen therapy in severe cases

Sinusitis.Description: Inflammation of the sinuses, often causing congestion and pain.
Sinusitis.Symptoms: Facial pain/pressure, nasal congestion, runny nose, loss of smell, cough, sore throat
Sinusitis.Causes: Viral infections(like cold or flu), bacterial infections, allergies, nasal polyps
Sinusitis.Prevention: Avoid colds, manage allergies, stay hydrated, use a humidifier, good nasal hygiene
Sinusitis.Treatment: Nasal sprays, decongestants, saline rinses, antibiotics( for bacterial sinusitis), antihistamines

Pharyngitis(Sore Throat).Description: Inflammation of the throat, often resulting in pain and discomfort.
Pharyngitis(Sore Throat).Symptoms: Sore throat, pain when swallowing, swollen tonsils, hoarseness, fever, cough
Pharyngitis(Sore Throat).Causes: Viral infections(common cold, flu), bacterial infections(strep throat), allergies, dry air
Pharyngitis(Sore Throat).Prevention: Good hand hygiene, avoiding contact with sick individuals, staying hydrated, using humidifiers
Pharyngitis(Sore Throat).Treatment: (Viral pharyngitis is typically treated symptomatically without antibiotics); pain relivers(e.g., ibuprofen, acetaminophen), throat lozenges, antibiotics(for bacterial infection), rest

Laryngitis.Description: Inflammation of the larynx, typically causing hoarseness.
Laryngitis.Symptoms: Hoarseness, loss of voice, sore throat, dry cough, throat irritation, difficulty speaking
Laryngitis.Causes: Viral infections(common cold, flu), overuse of voice, bacterial infections, smoking, allergies
Laryngitis.Prevention: Avoid excessive use of voice, stay hydrated, avoid smoking, manage allergies, good hand hygiene
Laryngitis.Treatment: Resting the voice, stay hydrated, humidifiers, pain relievers, antibiotics(if bacterial), corticosteriods(in severe cases)

Gastroenteritis(Stomach Flu).Description: An intestinal infection causing diarrhea and stomach cramps.
Gastroenteritis(Stomach Flu).Symptoms: Watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, low-grade fever, muscle aches
Gastroenteritis(Stomach Flu).Causes: Viral Infections(Norovirus, Rotavirus, Astrovirus, Adenovirus), contaminated food or water
Gastroenteritis(Stomach Flu).Prevention: Good hand hygiene, drinking clean water, proper food preparation, avoiding contaminated food
Gastroenteritis(Stomach Flu).Treatment: Rehydration(oral rehydration salts, IV fluids if severe), anti-nausea medications, metronidazole(for bacterial cases), loperamide(for diarrhea control)

Tonsilitis.Description: Infection or inflammation of the tonsils.
Tonsilitis.Symptoms: Sore throat, difficulty swallowing, swollen tonsils, fever, bad breath, swollen lymph nodes
Tonsilitis.Causes: Viral or bacterial infections (commonly Group A Streptococcus)
Tonsilitis.Prevention: Good hygiene, avoiding contact with infected individuals, hand washing
Tonsilitis.Treatment: Rest, fluids, pain relievers (ibuprofen or acetaminophen), antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin for bacterial tonsillitis)

Food Poisining.Description: An illness caused by ingesting contaminated food, leading to gastrointestinal distress.
Food Poisining.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, fever, weakness, dehydration
Food Poisining.Causes: Contaminated food or water (bacteria, viruses, parasites, toxins)
Food Poisining.Prevention: Proper food handling, cooking food to the correct temperature, hand washing, avoiding raw/contaminated food
Food Poisining.Treatment: Rest, hydration, oral rehydration solutions, IV fluids (in severe cases), antibiotics (for bacterial infections), anti-diarrheal medications (for some cases)

Irritable Bowel Syndrome.Description: A chronic condition that affects the large intestine, causing pain and irregular bowel movements.
Irritable Bowel Syndrome.Symptoms: Abdominal pain, cramping, bloating, gas, diarrhea or constipation, changes in bowel habits
Irritable Bowel Syndrome.Causes: Unknown, but can be related to abnormal muscle contractions in the intestines, nervous system dysfunction, inflammation in the intestines, severe infection, stress
Irritable Bowel Syndrome.Prevention: Manage stress, avoid trigger foods, eat high-fiber foods, regular exercise, probiotics, small meals
Irritable Bowel Syndrome.Treatment: Dietary changes, stress management, fiber supplements, laxatives (for constipation), anti-diarrheal medications, antispasmodic medications, antidepressants

Lactose Intolerance.Description: An inability to digest lactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products.
Lactose Intolerance.Symptoms: Diarrhea, nausea, abdominal cramps, bloating, gas after consuming dairy products
Lactose Intolerance.Causes: Lack of lactase enzyme in the small intestine, leading to difficulty digesting lactose (sugar in milk and dairy products)
Lactose Intolerance.Prevention: Avoid or limit dairy products, use lactose-free dairy products, take lactase enzyme supplements
Lactose Intolerance.Treatment: Dietary adjustments (lactose-free or low-lactose foods), lactase enzyme supplements, calcium and vitamin D supplements

Constipation.Description: Difficulty in passing stools, often due to a lack of fiber in the diet.
Constipation.Symptoms: Infrequent bowel movements (less than three times a week), difficulty passing stools, hard or dry stools, abdominal discomfort, bloating
Constipation.Causes: Lack of fiber in the diet, dehydration, lack of physical activity, certain medications, ignoring the urge to pass stool, changes in routine, stress
Constipation.Prevention: Eat a high-fiber diet (fruits, vegetables, whole grains), drink plenty of water, exercise regularly, establish a regular bathroom routine
Constipation.Treatment: Increased dietary fiber, stool softeners, laxatives (e.g., lactulose), increased water intake, regular exercise

Diarrhea.Description: Frequent, loose, or watery stools, usually due to infection or irritation.
Diarrhea.Symptoms: Loose, watery stools, frequent bowel movements, abdominal cramps, bloating, nausea, urgency to have a bowel movement, dehydration
Diarrhea.Causes: Viral infections (e.g., rotavirus, norovirus), bacterial infections (e.g., E. coli, salmonella), contaminated water or food, medications (e.g., antibiotics), intestinal diseases (IBS, IBD)
Diarrhea.Prevention: Safe drinking water, good sanitation, proper hygiene (handwashing), vaccination (e.g., rotavirus vaccine), food safety practices
Diarrhea.Treatment: Oral rehydration solution (ORS), zinc supplements, antidiarrheal medications (e.g., loperamide), increased fluid intake, continued feeding for children

Acid Reflux.Description: A digestive disorder where stomach acid flows back into the esophagus.
Acid Reflux.Symptoms: Heartburn, regurgitation of food or sour liquid, difficulty swallowing, chest pain, sensation of lump in throat, chronic cough, sore throat, hoarseness
Acid Reflux.Causes: Weakening of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), obesity, pregnancy, smoking, certain foods and drinks (spicy, fatty foods, alcohol, coffee), certain medications
Acid Reflux.Prevention: Maintain healthy weight, avoid trigger foods, stop smoking, eat smaller meals, avoid lying down after eating, raise the head of the bed
Acid Reflux.Treatment: Lifestyle changes (diet modification, weight loss), antacids, H2 blockers (e.g., famotidine), proton pump inhibitors (PPIs, e.g., omeprazole)

Peptic Ulcers.Description: Sores that develop on the lining of the stomach or small intestine.
Peptic Ulcers.Symptoms: Burning stomach pain, bloating, intolerance to fatty foods, heartburn, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, dark or black stools, vomiting blood
Peptic Ulcers.Causes: Helicobacter pylori infection, prolonged use of NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin, ibuprofen), smoking, excessive alcohol, stress, spicy foods
Peptic Ulcers.Prevention: Avoid long-term use of NSAIDs, quit smoking, limit alcohol, manage stress, eat a healthy diet
Peptic Ulcers.Treatment: Proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole), antibiotics for H. pylori (clarithromycin, amoxicillin), antacids, lifestyle changes (diet modification, quitting smoking)

Hemorrhoids.Description: Swollen veins in the rectum or anus, causing pain and bleeding.
Hemorrhoids.Symptoms: Pain or discomfort during bowel movements, itching or irritation in the anal region, swelling around the anus, bleeding during bowel movements, protrusion of tissue
Hemorrhoids.Causes: Straining during bowel movements, chronic constipation or diarrhea, sitting for long periods, obesity, pregnancy, anal intercourse, age-related tissue weakening
Hemorrhoids.Prevention: High-fiber diet, staying hydrated, regular exercise, avoiding prolonged sitting, practicing good bowel habits
Hemorrhoids.Treatment: Over-the-counter creams (e.g., hydrocortisone), topical analgesics, sitz baths, fiber supplements, in severe cases, surgical options such as hemorrhoidectomy or banding

Dermatitis(Eczema).Description: A chronic skin condition causing itchy, inflamed skin.
Dermatitis(Eczema).Symptoms: Red, inflamed skin, itching, dryness, cracking, scaling, thickened skin, blisters
Dermatitis(Eczema).Causes: Allergens (e.g., pollen, pet dander), irritants (e.g., soaps, detergents), genetic factors, stress, certain medical conditions
Dermatitis(Eczema).Prevention: Avoid known triggers, use mild soaps, moisturize regularly, wear protective clothing, practice stress management
Dermatitis(Eczema).Treatment: Topical corticosteroids, antihistamines for itching, moisturizers, calcineurin inhibitors, phototherapy in severe cases

Psoriasis.Description: A skin disease causing red, scaly patches on the skin.
Psoriasis.Symptoms: Red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales, dry and cracked skin that may bleed, itching and burning sensations, thickened or pitted nails, swollen joints
Psoriasis.Causes: Genetic factors, immune system dysfunction, environmental triggers (stress, infections, skin injuries), and certain medications
Psoriasis.Prevention: Avoid known triggers, maintain a healthy lifestyle, manage stress, use moisturizers regularly
Psoriasis.Treatment: Topical treatments (corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs), phototherapy, systemic medications (e.g., methotrexate, biologics) for severe cases

Acne.Description: A skin condition where hair follicles become clogged, causing pimples.
Acne.Symptoms: Pimples, whiteheads, blackheads, cysts, nodules, and red, swollen, or painful skin
Acne.Causes: Excess oil (sebum) production, clogged hair follicles, bacteria, hormonal changes (e.g., puberty), certain medications, diet, stress
Acne.Prevention: Clean skin regularly, avoid oily skincare products, maintain a healthy diet, manage stress, avoid picking or squeezing pimples
Acne.Treatment: Topical treatments (retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid), antibiotics (oral or topical), hormonal treatments (e.g., birth control), isotretinoin for severe cases

Fungal Infection.Description: An infection caused by fungi, often affecting the skin, nails, or lungs.
Fungal Infection.Symptoms: Skin rashes, itching, redness, scaling, blisters, cracking skin, nail discoloration, respiratory issues, and fatigue (depending on the type of fungal infection)
Fungal Infection.Causes: Exposure to fungi (e.g., Candida, Aspergillus, Cryptococcus), weakened immune system, warm and moist environments, inhalation of spores
Fungal Infection.Prevention: Keep skin clean and dry, avoid sharing personal items, wear breathable clothing, maintain good hygiene, avoid contact with infected individuals
Fungal Infection.Treatment: Antifungal medications (oral or topical): Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Terbinafine, Amphotericin B (for severe cases); good hygiene and keeping the affected area dry

Cold Sores(Herpes Simplex Virus).Description: Painful blisters around the mouth caused by the herpes simplex virus.
Cold Sores(Herpes Simplex Virus).Symptoms: Tingling, itching, small fluid-filled blisters around the mouth, lips, or nose; pain and discomfort; fever in severe cases
Cold Sores(Herpes Simplex Virus).Causes: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1, and sometimes HSV-2); usually spread through close personal contact, saliva, or shared objects like utensils
Cold Sores(Herpes Simplex Virus).Prevention: Avoid close contact with infected individuals, avoid sharing personal items (lip balm, utensils), use sunscreen on the lips to prevent flare-ups
Cold Sores(Herpes Simplex Virus).Treatment: Antiviral medications (e.g., Valacyclovir, Acyclovir); topical creams (e.g., Docosanol) to reduce duration and discomfort; stay hydrated, use cold compresses

Impetigo.Description: A contagious skin infection often seen in children.
Impetigo.Symptoms: Red sores that quickly rupture, ooze for a few days, and then form a yellowish-brown crust; mostly around the nose and mouth, and sometimes hands and feet
Impetigo.Causes: Bacterial infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes; usually spread by contact with an infected person or contaminated objects
Impetigo.Prevention: Good hygiene, regular hand washing, keeping wounds clean, and avoiding contact with infected individuals or shared personal items
Impetigo.Treatment: Antibiotics, typically topical (Mupirocin or Fusidic Acid) for mild cases; oral antibiotics (e.g., Amoxicillin-Clavulanate, Cephalexin) for more severe cases

Hives(Urticaria).Description: A skin rash with red, itchy welts, often due to an allergic reaction.
Hives(Urticaria).Symptoms: Raised, itchy welts (hives) on the skin; can appear suddenly and vary in size; may cause burning or stinging sensations; can be accompanied by angioedema (swelling)
Hives(Urticaria).Causes: Allergic reactions, stress, infections, medications, certain foods, and physical factors (temperature, sunlight, pressure)
Hives(Urticaria).Prevention: Identify and avoid known triggers; manage stress; maintain good hygiene
Hives(Urticaria).Treatment: Antihistamines (e.g., Cetirizine, Loratadine); corticosteroids for severe cases; avoiding known triggers; cold compresses for relief

Hay Fever.Description: An allergic response causing sneezing and nasal congestion.
Hay Fever.Symptoms: Sneezing, runny or stuffy nose, itchy eyes, mouth or throat, watery eyes, fatigue, cough, and postnasal drip
Hay Fever.Causes: Allergic reactions to pollen from trees, grasses, and weeds; mold spores; pet dander; dust mites; and certain foods
Hay Fever.Prevention: Avoid known allergens; use air conditioning; keep windows closed during pollen season; use high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters; take preventive medications
Hay Fever.Treatment: Antihistamines (e.g., Cetirizine, Loratadine); nasal corticosteroids (e.g., Fluticasone); decongestants; allergy shots (immunotherapy)

Allergic Rhinitis.Description: An allergic condition causing inflammation in the nasal passages.
Allergic Rhinitis.Symptoms: Sneezing, runny or stuffy nose, itchy eyes, itchy throat, postnasal drip, fatigue, coughing, and wheezing
Allergic Rhinitis.Causes: Allergens such as pollen, dust mites, mold, pet dander, and certain foods
Allergic Rhinitis.Prevention: Avoidance of known allergens, use of air conditioning, keeping windows closed during pollen season, using hypoallergenic bedding, and regular cleaning
Allergic Rhinitis.Treatment: Antihistamines (e.g., Cetirizine, Loratadine), nasal corticosteroids (e.g., Fluticasone), decongestants, and allergen immunotherapy (allergy shots)

Food Allergy.Description: An abnormal immune response to specific foods.
Food Allergy.Symptoms: Hives, itching, swelling of lips or tongue, difficulty breathing, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and anaphylaxis in severe cases
Food Allergy.Causes: Allergens such as peanuts, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, eggs, milk, soy, and wheat
Food Allergy.Prevention: Avoidance of known allergens, reading food labels, and consultation with an allergist for management and possible desensitization therapy
Food Allergy.Treatment: Antihistamines for mild reactions; epinephrine auto-injectors (e.g., EpiPen) for severe reactions (anaphylaxis)

Tendinitis.Description: Inflammation of the tendons, often due to overuse.
Tendinitis.Symptoms: Pain, tenderness, and stiffness in the affected tendon, swelling, and limited range of motion in the joint near the tendon
Tendinitis.Causes: Overuse or repetitive motion, injury, aging, and certain medical conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis)
Tendinitis.Prevention: Stretching and strengthening exercises, proper warm-up before activities, using ergonomic tools, and avoiding repetitive motions
Tendinitis.Treatment: Rest, ice application, over-the-counter pain relievers (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen), physical therapy, corticosteroid injections, and, in severe cases, surgery

Otitis Media(Ear Infection).Description: A middle ear infection common in children.
Otitis Media(Ear Infection).Symptoms: Ear pain, difficulty hearing, fluid drainage from the ear, fever, irritability in children, and balance issues
Otitis Media(Ear Infection).Causes: Bacterial or viral infections, allergies, respiratory infections, and blockage of the Eustachian tube
Otitis Media(Ear Infection).Prevention: Keeping vaccinations up to date, avoiding secondhand smoke exposure, practicing good hygiene, and managing allergies
Otitis Media(Ear Infection).Treatment: Observation, antibiotics for bacterial infections, pain relief with acetaminophen or ibuprofen, warm compresses, and in some cases, surgical intervention (e.g., tympanostomy tubes)

Otitis Externa(Swimmer's Ear).Description: An outer ear infection often due to water exposure.
Otitis Externa(Swimmer's Ear).Symptoms: Ear pain, itching in the ear canal, redness inside the ear, fluid drainage, hearing loss, and swelling
Otitis Externa(Swimmer's Ear).Causes: Bacterial infection from water exposure (commonly known as “swimmer’s ear”), excessive moisture in the ear, skin conditions like eczema, or foreign object injury
Otitis Externa(Swimmer's Ear).Prevention: Keep ears dry, avoid inserting objects in the ear, use earplugs when swimming, and treat skin conditions that affect the ear canal
Otitis Externa(Swimmer's Ear).Treatment: Topical antibiotics (ear drops), corticosteroids to reduce inflammation, pain relief, and keeping the ear dry

Tinnitus.Description: Ringing or other noises in one or both ears not caused by an external sound.
Tinnitus.Symptoms: Ringing, buzzing, hissing, roaring, or clicking sounds in the ears that are not caused by external noise
Tinnitus.Causes: Exposure to loud noises, ear infections, earwax buildup, age-related hearing loss, ototoxic medications, and underlying conditions such as high blood pressure
Tinnitus.Prevention: Protect ears from loud noises, use ear protection, avoid prolonged exposure to high-volume environments, maintain cardiovascular health, and avoid ototoxic substances
Tinnitus.Treatment: No specific cure; treatments include sound therapy, hearing aids, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and managing underlying conditions (e.g., earwax removal)

Nosebleeds(Epistaxis).Description: Bleeding from the nose, often due to dry air or injury.
Nosebleeds(Epistaxis).Symptoms: Bleeding from one or both nostrils, which can range from light to heavy; can be sudden or frequent; may be accompanied by lightheadedness or dizziness in severe cases
Nosebleeds(Epistaxis).Causes: Dry air, nose picking, nasal trauma, allergies, upper respiratory infections, blood-thinning medications, hypertension, and bleeding disorders
Nosebleeds(Epistaxis).Prevention: Use of humidifiers, avoiding nose picking or blowing too hard, keeping nasal passages moist (e.g., with saline sprays), treating underlying conditions (e.g., allergies), and avoiding excessive use of nasal decongestants
Nosebleeds(Epistaxis).Treatment: Pinching the nostrils and leaning forward, applying cold compresses, and using nasal packing; if persistent, cauterization, nasal tampons, or medical evaluation may be required

Nasal Polyps.Description: Non-cancerous growths on the lining of the nasal passages or sinuses.
Nasal Polyps.Symptoms: Persistent nasal congestion, runny nose, reduced or absent sense of smell, postnasal drip, facial pain or pressure, snoring, and in severe cases, difficulty breathing
Nasal Polyps.Causes: Chronic inflammation of the nasal passages due to asthma, allergies, chronic sinus infections, or immune system responses; also linked to conditions like aspirin sensitivity and cystic fibrosis
Nasal Polyps.Prevention: Managing allergies and asthma, avoiding nasal irritants, practicing good nasal hygiene (e.g., using saline sprays), and treating infections and inflammation early
Nasal Polyps.Treatment: Corticosteroid nasal sprays (e.g., mometasone) to reduce inflammation; oral corticosteroids or surgery (polypectomy) may be required for severe or persistent cases

Vertigo.Description: A sensation of spinning or dizziness, often linked to inner ear issues.
Vertigo.Symptoms: Sensation of spinning, dizziness, loss of balance, nausea, vomiting, headaches, abnormal eye movements, and difficulty walking
Vertigo.Causes: Inner ear disorders (e.g., benign paroxysmal positional vertigo - BPPV, Meniere’s disease, labyrinthitis), head injuries, migraines, stroke, or vestibular neuritis
Vertigo.Prevention: Managing underlying conditions (e.g., ear infections, migraines), avoiding sudden head movements, and practicing balance exercises
Vertigo.Treatment: Medications like meclizine for dizziness, antihistamines, or vestibular rehabilitation therapy (VRT); in severe cases, surgery may be necessary to correct inner ear issues

Sore Throat.Description: Pain in the throat often caused by infection or irritation.
Sore Throat.Symptoms: Pain or scratchy sensation in the throat, difficulty swallowing, swollen glands in the neck or jaw, hoarse voice, and red or swollen tonsils
Sore Throat.Causes: Viral infections (e.g., common cold, flu, COVID-19), bacterial infections (e.g., strep throat), allergies, dry air, irritants (smoke, pollution), or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
Sore Throat.Prevention: Practice good hygiene (handwashing), avoid close contact with sick individuals, stay hydrated, avoid smoking, and use a humidifier in dry environments
Sore Throat.Treatment: Over-the-counter pain relievers (ibuprofen or acetaminophen), throat lozenges, saltwater gargles, staying hydrated; for bacterial infections, antibiotics like amoxicillin may be prescribed

Conjunctivitis.Description: Inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eye.
Conjunctivitis.Symptoms: Redness in the white of the eye or inner eyelid, increased tear production, itching, irritation, discharge (yellow or green), crusting of the eyelids or lashes, sensitivity to light
Conjunctivitis.Causes: Viral infections (e.g., adenovirus), bacterial infections (e.g., Staphylococcus or Streptococcus), allergies (e.g., pollen, dust mites), chemical exposure, or irritants (e.g., smoke, contact lenses)
Conjunctivitis.Prevention: Practice good hygiene (handwashing, avoiding touching eyes), avoid sharing personal items (towels, eye makeup), change pillowcases regularly, and use protective eyewear in hazardous environments
Conjunctivitis.Treatment: Viral conjunctivitis usually resolves on its own; bacterial conjunctivitis may require antibiotic eye drops or ointments; allergic conjunctivitis can be treated with antihistamine or anti-inflammatory eye drops

Styes.Description: A painful lump on the eyelid caused by a blocked gland.
Styes.Symptoms: Red, swollen lump on the edge of the eyelid (often resembling a pimple), tenderness or pain in the affected area, increased tearing, sensitivity to light, a sensation of something in the eye
Styes.Causes: Bacterial infection (usually Staphylococcus) in the oil glands at the base of the eyelashes or in the eyelid follicles
Styes.Prevention: Maintain good eye hygiene (clean eyelids regularly), avoid rubbing eyes with unclean hands, remove makeup before sleeping, replace old makeup, avoid sharing personal items like towels
Styes.Treatment: Warm compress applied to the affected eye for 5-10 minutes several times a day, keeping the eye clean, over-the-counter pain relievers, antibiotic ointments or eye drops for bacterial infection if prescribed, incision and drainage if necessary (performed by a doctor)

Dry Eye Syndrome.Description: A condition where the eyes don't produce enough tears.
Dry Eye Syndrome.Symptoms: Dryness, burning, stinging, redness, blurred vision, light sensitivity
Dry Eye Syndrome.Causes: Aging, environmental factors, hormonal changes, medications, autoimmune conditions
Dry Eye Syndrome.Prevention: Limit screen time, take regular breaks from screens, use a humidifier, avoid smoke or windy environments, wear sunglasses outdoors, stay hydrated
Dry Eye Syndrome.Treatment: Artificial tears, cyclosporine drops, punctal plugs, warm compresses, eyelid hygiene, omega-3 supplements

Allergic Conjunctivitis.Description: An allergic reaction causing redness and itching in the eyes.
Allergic Conjunctivitis.Symptoms: Itchy eyes, redness, swelling, watery discharge
Allergic Conjunctivitis.Causes: Allergens like pollen, dust mites, mold spores, pet dander
Allergic Conjunctivitis.Prevention: Avoid allergens, keep windows closed during high pollen seasons, use air purifiers, wear sunglasses outside
Allergic Conjunctivitis.Treatment: Antihistamines, decongestants, eye drops, steroid eye drops

Blepharitis.Description: Inflammation of the eyelids, often due to an infection or blockage.
Blepharitis.Symptoms: Red, swollen eyelids, flaking skin, burning sensation, crusting along the eyelashes
Blepharitis.Causes: Bacterial infections, clogged oil glands, dandruff, allergies
Blepharitis.Prevention: Proper eyelid hygiene, avoid touching the eyes, use warm compresses
Blepharitis.Treatment: Warm compresses, eyelid scrubs, antibiotics, steroid eye drops

Chalazion.Description: A cyst in the eyelid caused by a blocked gland.
Chalazion.Symptoms: Painless lump on the eyelid, redness, swelling
Chalazion.Causes: Blocked oil glands, poor eyelid hygiene, chronic blepharitis
Chalazion.Prevention: Maintain eyelid hygiene, avoid rubbing eyes
Chalazion.Treatment: Warm compresses, eyelid hygiene, antibiotic ointments if infected, surgical drainage if necessary

Urinary Tract Infection.Description: A bacterial infection of the urinary tract, common in women.
Urinary Tract Infection.Symptoms: Painful urination, frequent urination, cloudy or foul-smelling urine, pelvic pain
Urinary Tract Infection.Causes: Bacterial infections (E. coli), sexual activity, poor hygiene, urinary catheter use
Urinary Tract Infection.Prevention: Hydration, proper hygiene, urinate after intercourse, avoid holding in urine
Urinary Tract Infection.Treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., trimethoprim, nitrofurantoin), increased fluid intake

Yeast Infection(Candidiasis).Description: A yeast infection in the vagina, often causing itching and discharge.
Yeast Infection(Candidiasis).Symptoms: Itching, irritation, thick white discharge resembling cottage cheese, redness, swelling, pain during intercourse, burning during urination
Yeast Infection(Candidiasis).Causes: Overgrowth of Candida yeast, often triggered by antibiotic use, hormonal changes (e.g., pregnancy, menstrual cycle), weakened immune system, diabetes, or certain medications
Yeast Infection(Candidiasis).Prevention: Avoid wearing tight clothing, use breathable underwear, avoid unnecessary antibiotics, maintain a balanced diet
Yeast Infection(Candidiasis).Treatment: Over-the-counter antifungal creams (e.g., clotrimazole, miconazole), oral antifungal medication (e.g., fluconazole), maintain hygiene, and follow up with a healthcare provider if symptoms persist

Bladder Infection(Interstitial Cystitis).Description: Inflammation of the bladder, causing pelvic pain and discomfort.
Bladder Infection(Interstitial Cystitis).Symptoms: Frequent and urgent need to urinate, pain during urination, pelvic pain, discomfort in the bladder, pressure in the bladder, pain during sexual intercourse
Bladder Infection(Interstitial Cystitis).Causes: The exact cause is often unknown; potential triggers include bladder irritation, infections, autoimmune disorders, or nerve damage; may be linked to certain foods, beverages, or stress
Bladder Infection(Interstitial Cystitis).Prevention: Avoid irritants such as caffeine, alcohol, spicy foods, and artificial sweeteners; practice good hygiene, stay hydrated, and empty the bladder regularly; manage stress and seek treatment for recurrent infections
Bladder Infection(Interstitial Cystitis).Treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, fosfomycin), pain relief with NSAIDs

Bacterial Vaginosis.Description: An imbalance of bacteria in the vagina, causing discharge and odor.
Bacterial Vaginosis.Symptoms: Thin, gray or white vaginal discharge, a fishy odor (especially after intercourse), vaginal itching, and burning during urination. Some women may have no symptoms at all.
Bacterial Vaginosis.Causes: An imbalance in the normal bacteria found in the vagina, often caused by an overgrowth of certain bacteria, and factors such as multiple sexual partners, douching, and lack of lactobacilli (the good bacteria).
Bacterial Vaginosis.Prevention: Practice good hygiene, avoid douching, limit the number of sexual partners, use condoms, and maintain a healthy vaginal flora.

Headaches(Tension).Description: Headaches caused by muscle tension in the head, neck, and shoulders.
Headaches(Tension).Symptoms: Dull, aching pain around the forehead or neck, tightness or pressure sensation
Headaches(Tension).Causes: Muscle tension in the head, neck, and shoulders, stress, anxiety, fatigue, poor posture, skipping meals, eye strain, and dehydration
Headaches(Tension).Prevention: Manage stress through relaxation techniques (e.g., yoga, meditation), maintain good posture, stay hydrated, establish regular sleep patterns, and avoid triggers like skipping meals or excessive screen time
Headaches(Tension).Treatment: Over-the-counter pain relievers (e.g., ibuprofen, acetaminophen), stress reduction techniques

Migraine.Description: Severe headaches often accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light.
Migraine.Symptoms: Throbbing pain, sensitivity to light and sound, nausea, visual disturbances (aura)
Migraine.Causes: Genetic factors, stress, hormonal changes, certain foods, sensory stimuli
Migraine.Prevention: Avoid known triggers (e.g., certain foods, stress), maintain regular sleep patterns, stay hydrated
Migraine.Treatment: NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen), triptans, anti-nausea medications, preventive medications (e.g., beta-blockers, anti-seizure drugs)

Insomnia(short-term).Description: Temporary difficulty in falling or staying asleep.
Insomnia(short-term).Symptoms: Difficulty falling or staying asleep, waking up too early, daytime fatigue
Insomnia(short-term).Causes: Stress, jet lag, shift work, caffeine or alcohol consumption, medications
Insomnia(short-term).Prevention: Limit caffeine intake, avoid naps during the day, establish a regular sleep routine, avoid screen time before bed
Insomnia(short-term).Treatment: Sleep aids (e.g., melatonin), cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), relaxation techniques

Restless Leg Syndrome.Description: A condition causing an uncontrollable urge to move the legs.
Restless Leg Syndrome.Symptoms: Uncomfortable sensations in the legs (itching, tingling, crawling), urge to move legs, difficulty sleeping
Restless Leg Syndrome.Causes: Genetic factors, low iron levels, pregnancy, kidney failure, medications (e.g., antidepressants, antihistamines)
Restless Leg Syndrome.Prevention: Regular exercise, iron supplements, avoid caffeine and alcohol, establish a sleep routine
Restless Leg Syndrome.Treatment: Dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole), iron supplements, anti-seizure drugs (e.g., gabapentin)

Chickenpox.Description: A contagious viral illness causing an itchy rash.
Chickenpox.Symptoms: Itchy red spots or blisters, fever, fatigue, loss of appetite
Chickenpox.Prevention: Vaccination, avoid contact with infected individuals, maintain proper hygiene
Chickenpox.Treatment: Antihistamines for itching, acetaminophen for fever, antiviral medications (e.g., acyclovir) for severe cases

Measels.Description: A viral infection causing a red rash and flu-like symptoms.
Measels.Symptoms: High fever, cough, runny nose, red eyes, red blotchy rash
Measels.Prevention: Vaccination (MMR), avoid contact with infected individuals
Measels.Treatment: Acetaminophen for fever, vitamin A supplements, hydration

Mumps.Description: A viral infection affecting the salivary glands, causing swelling.
Mumps.Symptoms: Swollen salivary glands, fever, headache, fatigue, muscle aches
Mumps.Prevention: Vaccination (MMR), avoid contact with infected individuals
Mumps.Treatment: Acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain and fever, cold compresses, hydration

Rubella.Description: A contagious viral disease causing a red rash.
Rubella.Symptoms: Low-grade fever, rash, swollen lymph nodes, joint pain
Rubella.Prevention: Vaccination (MMR), avoid contact with infected individuals
Rubella.Treatment: Acetaminophen for fever and pain, rest, hydration

Scarlet Fever.Description: A bacterial illness causing a high fever and rash.
Scarlet Fever.Symptoms: High fever, sore throat, red rash (feels like sandpaper), strawberry tongue
Scarlet Fever.Prevention: Proper hygiene (e.g., handwashing), avoid contact with infected individuals
Scarlet Fever.Treatment: Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin, amoxicillin), acetaminophen for fever

Hand, Foot, and Mouth Diseases.Description: A viral infection causing fever, sore throat, and a rash on the hands, feet, and mouth.
Hand, Foot, and Mouth Diseases.Symptoms: Fever, sore throat, painful sores in the mouth, rash on the hands and feet, loss of appetite, irritability in infants and toddlers
Hand, Foot, and Mouth Diseases.Causes: Viral infection, most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16; spreads through close personal contact, respiratory droplets, and contaminated surfaces
Hand, Foot, and Mouth Diseases.Prevention: Wash hands frequently, disinfect surfaces and objects, avoid close contact with infected individuals, and keep children at home when they are ill
Hand, Foot, and Mouth Diseases.Treatment: No specific antiviral treatment; management focuses on relieving symptoms; pain relievers (e.g., acetaminophen), mouth rinses for sores, hydration to prevent dehydration, and soft foods to ease eating discomfort

Mononucleosis.Description: A viral infection often known as the kissing disease.
Mononucleosis.Symptoms: Fatigue, fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, swollen spleen
Mononucleosis.Prevention: Avoid sharing utensils or drinks, practice good hygiene
Mononucleosis.Treatment: Rest, hydration, acetaminophen or ibuprofen for pain and fever, corticosteroids in severe cases

Chlamydia.Description: A sexually transmitted infection caused by bacteria.
Chlamydia.Symptoms: Painful urination, abnormal vaginal or penile discharge, pain during intercourse, pelvic pain
Chlamydia.Causes: Bacterial infection (Chlamydia trachomatis), spread through sexual contact
Chlamydia.Prevention: Use condoms during intercourse, get regular STD screenings

Gonorrhea.Description: A bacterial sexually transmitted infection affecting the genitals.
Gonorrhea.Symptoms: Painful urination, abnormal discharge from genitals, pain during intercourse, pelvic pain
Gonorrhea.Causes: Bacterial infection (Neisseria gonorrhoeae), spread through sexual contact
Gonorrhea.Prevention: Use condoms during intercourse, get regular STD screenings

Herpes.Description: A viral sexually transmitted infection causing blisters.
Herpes.Symptoms: Painful blisters or sores around the mouth or genitals, fever, body aches, swollen lymph nodes
Herpes.Causes: Herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 and HSV-2), spread through direct contact with infected areas
Herpes.Prevention: Use condoms during intercourse, avoid direct contact with sores, get regular STD screenings
Herpes.Treatment: Antiviral medications (e.g., acyclovir, valacyclovir), pain relief

Human Papillomavirus.Description: A common sexually transmitted infection caused by human papillomavirus.
Human Papillomavirus.Symptoms: Genital warts, abnormal Pap smear results, possible progression to cervical cancer
Human Papillomavirus.Causes: Human papillomavirus (HPV), spread through sexual contact
Human Papillomavirus.Prevention: HPV vaccination, use condoms during intercourse, get regular Pap smears
Human Papillomavirus.Treatment: No treatment for the virus itself (warts may be treated with topical solutions), vaccination for prevention

Iron Deficiency.Description: A condition where there is a lack of iron in the body, causing fatigue.
Iron Deficiency.Symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness
Iron Deficiency.Causes: Lack of dietary iron, blood loss, pregnancy, inability to absorb iron
Iron Deficiency.Prevention: Eat iron-rich foods (e.g., red meat, spinach), take iron supplements, manage blood loss, avoid tea/coffee with meals
Iron Deficiency.Treatment: Iron supplements (ferrous sulfate), dietary changes, vitamin C supplements to aid absorption

Varicose Veins.Description: Enlarged veins in the legs, causing pain and discomfort.
Varicose Veins.Symptoms: Bulging, twisted veins (usually in the legs), leg pain, swelling, heaviness
Varicose Veins.Causes: Genetic factors, prolonged standing or sitting, obesity, pregnancy
Varicose Veins.Prevention: Regular exercise, avoid prolonged sitting or standing, elevate legs, wear compression stockings
Varicose Veins.Treatment: Compression stockings, lifestyle changes (exercise, weight loss), laser therapy or sclerotherapy for severe cases

Thrombophlebitis.Description: Inflammation of a vein, often in the legs, sometimes with a blood clot.
Thrombophlebitis.Symptoms: Pain, swelling, redness along a vein, warmth in the affected area
Thrombophlebitis.Causes: Blood clotting in the veins (usually in the legs), prolonged inactivity, injury to the vein, varicose veins
Thrombophlebitis.Prevention: Avoid prolonged inactivity, stay hydrated, avoid injury to the veins, wear compression stockings
Thrombophlebitis.Treatment: Blood thinners (anticoagulants), compression stockings, elevation of the legs, lifestyle changes

Dehydration.Description: A condition where the body loses more fluids than it takes in.
Dehydration.Symptoms: Dry mouth, dark urine, dizziness, fatigue, confusion
Dehydration.Causes: Lack of fluid intake, excessive sweating, diarrhea or vomiting, heat exposure
Dehydration.Prevention: Drink plenty of fluids, avoid excessive heat, replace fluids lost during exercise
Dehydration.Treatment: Oral rehydration solutions, intravenous fluids (in severe cases), rest

Heat Exhaustion.Description: A heat-related illness causing heavy sweating and weakness.
Heat Exhaustion.Symptoms: Heavy sweating, weakness, dizziness, headache, nausea, fainting
Heat Exhaustion.Causes: Prolonged exposure to high temperatures, dehydration, vigorous physical activity
Heat Exhaustion.Prevention: Stay hydrated, avoid prolonged exposure to high temperatures, take frequent breaks in cool areas
Heat Exhaustion.Treatment: Rest in a cool place, hydration (oral or IV), cooling measures (e.g., cold compresses)

Motion Sickness.Description: Nausea or vomiting caused by motion.
Motion Sickness.Causes: Movement (e.g., car, boat, or plane travel), conflicting signals between the inner ear and the brain
Motion Sickness.Prevention: Sit in a stable seat (e.g., front of the car, middle of the boat), focus on the horizon, use acupressure bands
Motion Sickness.Treatment: Anti-nausea medications (e.g., dimenhydrinate, meclizine), ginger supplements

Jet Lag.Description: A temporary sleep disorder following long flights.
Jet Lag.Symptoms: Fatigue, insomnia, difficulty concentrating, mood changes
Jet Lag.Causes: Disruption of the body's circadian rhythm due to long-distance travel across multiple time zones
Jet Lag.Prevention: Gradually adjust to the new time zone before travel, stay hydrated, avoid caffeine and alcohol
Jet Lag.Treatment: Sleep aids (e.g., melatonin), adjusting sleep schedule, exposure to natural light

Hyperhidrosis(Excessive Sweating).Description: Excessive sweating often due to overactive sweat glands.
Hyperhidrosis(Excessive Sweating).Symptoms: Excessive sweating (especially of the hands, feet, and underarms), damp skin, body odor
Hyperhidrosis(Excessive Sweating).Causes: Overactive sweat glands, nervous system response to heat, stress, or exercise
Hyperhidrosis(Excessive Sweating).Prevention: Wear breathable clothing, use antiperspirants, avoid stress triggers
Hyperhidrosis(Excessive Sweating).Treatment: Antiperspirants, iontophoresis, botulinum toxin injections (Botox), prescription medications (e.g., anticholinergics)

Tetanus.Description: A serious bacterial infection causing muscle stiffness and spasms.
Tetanus.Symptoms: Muscle stiffness and spasms, difficulty swallowing, seizures, fever, high blood pressure
Tetanus.Causes: Bacterial infection (Clostridium tetani) through wounds or cuts
Tetanus.Treatment: Antitoxin (tetanus immune globulin), antibiotics (e.g., metronidazole), wound care

Tuberculosis.Description: A bacterial infection affecting the lungs and respiratory system.
Tuberculosis.Symptoms: Cough (lasting 3+ weeks), chest pain, coughing up blood, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats
Tuberculosis.Causes: Bacterial infection (Mycobacterium tuberculosis), spread through the air (coughing, sneezing)
Tuberculosis.Prevention: Vaccination (BCG), avoid close contact with infected individuals, maintain good hygiene
Tuberculosis.Treatment: Antibiotics like rifampicin, isoniazid, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide
